awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Disentangling how community composition differentially acts on multiple determinants of transmission in a directly-transmitted zoonotic pathogen
awd_abstract_narration:
Biodiversity is disappearing at an alarming rate, and at the same time, infectious diseases increasingly spill over from wildlife to humans. Therefore, it is urgent to understand how biodiversity affects infectious diseases in wildlife. In some ecosystems, a more diverse community decreases disease risk, termed the 'dilution' effect because biodiversity dilutes out infection. However, in other systems, a more diverse community increases disease risk, termed the 'amplification' effect. When to expect dilution or amplification is a topic of debate among disease ecologists. This project aims to reconcile the competing effects of biodiversity on disease risk using Sin Nombre hantavirus (SNV) in deer mice as a model, which displays aspects of both dilution and amplification in the same system at the same time. Researchers will examine how biodiversity can have competing effects by examining the underlying mechanisms, especially how competition between deer mice and other species in the community affects disease dynamics. This research will help unify the theories of dilution vs. amplification. It will also benefit society by advancing prevention efforts for hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS), which has infected more than 700 people (and killed more than 250) since its discovery in 1993. HPS has disproportionately affected Native Americans, who will be involved in this research on tribal lands. 

This project will test the hypothesis that competition between deer mice and other small mammal competitors affects host density, contact rates among hosts, and the probability of transmission from an infected to an uninfected host given contact between them. Based on previous observational studies, SNV displays an overall dilution effect through a decrease in deer mouse density with increased small mammal diversity, but also a component amplification effect through an increase in the transmission rate (a product of the contact rate for a given host density and the probability of transmission given contact). Here, researchers will test whether competition between deer mice and other small mammals drives both of these observed patterns. Aim 1 will determine if the decrease in deer mouse density is a result of competition or some other aspect of diversity, habitat type, or environmental conditions, using Bayesian analysis of long-term population data. Aim 2 will determine experimentally if an increase in competition leads to stress and depressed immunity and/or changes in behavior and contact rates (which affect the transmission rate). Deer mouse and competitor density will be manipulated in enclosures and contacts, stress, and immunity measured. Additionally, dynamics in an unmanipulated natural population will be monitored to expand interpretation of the experimental study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit:

Biodiversity is disappearing at an alarming rate, and at the same time, infectious diseases increasingly spill over from wildlife to humans. Therefore, it is urgent to understand how biodiversity affects infectious diseases in wildlife. In some ecosystems, a more diverse community decreases disease risk, termed the 'dilution' effect because biodiversity dilutes out infection. However, in other systems, a more diverse community increases disease risk, termed the 'amplification' effect. When to expect dilution or amplification is a topic of debate among disease ecologists. This EAGER proposal began to reconcile the competing effects of biodiversity by examining mechanisms driving these relationships, using Sin Nombre hantavirus (SNV) in deer mice (Image 1) as a model, which displays aspects of both dilution and amplification in the same system at the same time.

For directly-transmitted diseases, such as SNV, disease prevalence is determined by contact rates between individual hosts, immunity, and how individuals are contagious. If we want to understand when to expect dilution vs amplification, we need to understand the mechanisms that drive the relationships by examining how biodiversity could affect each of these. Biodiversity could potentially affect each of three parameters via 4 different mechanisms, shown in Image 2.

A systematic review of the literature revealed that regulation of host density is the most important mechanism driving if we see dilution vs amplification in rodent-hantavirus systems. In general, when 'diversity' equates to the presence of species that can reduce density of rodent hosts, such as competitors and predators, then we are more likely to see a dilution effect. If not, then we tend not to see a dilution effect. We found that relatively few studies examined more than one mechanism and none examined all the mechanisms simultaneously.

Our review also revealed that the effect of diversity on immunity has been neglected. To address this gap, we examined if small mammal diversity affects stress and immunity by capturing deer mice monthly over 2 years. (See Image 1.) We found evidence of increased stress with the presence of shrews and voles. Additionally, deer mice had more scars (so potentially more contacts) in the presence of shrews. These results are exciting because they suggest that small mammal competitors could affect both stress and contact rates, which are key determinants of pathogen transmission.

Since there was evidence of increased stress with small mammal competitors, we next asked whether stress led to changes in fitness or behavior, and which measures of stress were most predictive. We used Bayesian mark-recapture analysis to estimate survival and recapture rates and test between models using different stress metrics. We found that stress hormone metabolites better predicted trappability than survival, indicating there could be stress-induced changes in behavior. Body condition - a more generalized measure of health - was a better predictor of survival than any stress hormone measure. These results suggest that it is important to look for changes in behavior and recapture rates when examining stress-fitness relationships, and that more integrated measures of stress may be better indicators of fitness.

Since we found evidence that small mammal diversity can affect multiple mechanisms of disease transmission (density, stress, behavior), we explored the potential consequences of this using a novel theoretical model. Our work revealed that a non-monotonic, or hump-shaped, relationship is possible if multiple mechanisms are acting simultaneously. If competitors reduce the host population, but also have positive effects on transmission rate through increases in contacts or susceptibility, then there can be an amplification effect at lower diversities, which turns over as diversity increases, and becomes a dilution effect at higher diversities. Therefore, if we want to understand the effects of biodiversity on disease, it is important to consider multiple interacting mechanisms and whether there are synergies and antagonisms among mechanisms.

Lastly, we laid the groundwork for future studies by building and piloting the use of experimental enclosures for small mammals and developing Bayesian population models for analyzing long-term mark-recapture datasets. This work is the first to try to examine all possible mechanisms leading to dilution vs amplification for a directly-transmitted disease, laying the groundwork for a unified theory of how biodiversity can affect infectious disease in wildlife.

Broader Impacts: This project trained three graduate students, including a Native American and first-generation college and graduate student, from the Confederated Salish and Kootenai (CSK) Tribes; some of the field work was done on CSK tribal lands. Additionally, the project trained six undergraduate students, providing valuable hands-on experience in lab and fieldwork and communicating science to broader audiences. We reached scientific audiences through both oral and poster presentations at universities and local and national scientific conferences and peer-reviewed publications. We engaged the public through numerous news articles, webinars, and an interview on a popular science YouTube Channel.
